<leme no="78">

<page sig="a1r">
<f type="i">A short<f type="r"> 
D##sp##I##sp##C##sp##T##sp##I##sp##O##sp##N##sp##A##sp##R##sp##I##sp##E
FOR YONGE
BEGINNERS.
<f type="bl">Gathered of good
authours, spe&shy;
cially of

<f type="r">Columell, Grapald,
and Plini.

A##sp##N##sp##N##sp##O,
M. D, L V I.
</page>

<page sig="a1v">
</page>

<page sig="a2r">
T##sp##H##sp##E P##sp##R##sp##O##sp##L##sp##O##sp##G##sp##V##sp##E.
<f type="bl">To the ryght worshipfull syr Thomas
Chaloner knight, and clerke of the kynges
maiesties priuy counsaile.

<f type="bk">A<f type="bl">L beit ryght worshipful, that
this my treatise is bothe to vyle and base
to be set foorthe vnder your protection, be&shy;
yng worthily esteemed of all men, to be as
well learned wyse and vertuous, as any
gentleman in this realme, notwithst<expan type="a+_n">an</expan>ding
vpon hope of the humanitee and g<expan type="e+_">en</expan>tilnesse,
whiche is euer incident to persons of suche worthie qualitees,
I am at this present bolde, hauing no acqueintance with your
maistership to dedicate these my rude collections vnto you,
praiying you to accepte it as a thynge written by me to induce
children to the latine tonge, not moued therto with the desire
of vayne glory, but with a feru<expan type="e+_">en</expan>t affection & loue I beare vnto
my countrey. For accordyng vnto the saying of the deuine phi&shy;
losopher Plato, We are not borne onely for our owne c<expan type="o+_">om</expan>mo&shy;
ditee, but partly our parentes, partly our frendes, & partly our
countrey doth claime a certeine dewty of vs, whiche thynge
made Codrus kynge of Athens, Curtius & Decius Romayne
knightes, also zopirus the noble persian, with diuers others, to
ieopard their liues for the sauegarde of their countreis, which
examples of Infidels were suffici<expan type="e+_">en</expan>t to reproue me, if I shulde
refuse to take a little peyne for the profite of the publike
wealthe, and specially to preserue the tender youthe therof
from the infection of barbarousnesse, which therwith will bee
soone corrupte, not possible of longe tyme after to be restored.
For as Horace doth witnesse, the potte will longe sauour of 
the licour, wherwith it is seasoned. Also the finest colours
will sonest be staigned, neither can thei be so soone purified
and made cleane againe. These thynges considered, I haue 
resorted to the most famous and auncient authours, out of the
</page>

<page sig="a2v">
whiche as out of cleare fountaines I haue drawen as dili&shy;
gently as I coulde, the propre names of thynges conteyned
vnder one kind, &amp; disposed them in suche an ordre, that a very
childe beyng able to reade, may with litle labour perfitely im&shy;
print them in memory: Whiche shall not be onely profitable
for theim nowe in their tendre age, but hereafter when they 
shalbe of more iudgement and yeres, it shalbe vnto them a sin&shy;
gular treasure:for the lacke wherof thei shalbe compelled, as
I haue herde many profounde clerkes both in disputation as
also in familiar communication to vse in the stede of the pro&shy;
per and naturall woorde, a peraphrase or circumlocution.
Nowe if in the translatyng or in the englishyng of these wor&shy;
des I haue erred, as I can not but so do in so weighty a ma&shy;
tier, or if I haue omitted any thynge, as I haue doen many
purposely, because dyuers great learned men can not agree v&shy;
pon theim, I humbly submit my selfe to your maistershippes
correction, whom I knowe to bee excellently well learned
bothe in the Greeke and in the Latine, praiyng you hereafter,
whan occasion shall serue, to put your helpyng hande to the fi&shy;
nishyng of this litle booke, whiche if you dooe by the example
of syr Thomas Elyote that worthie knight, you shal not onely
bynde all that be studiouse to praye for you , but also purchase
to your selfe immortall fame and honour, whiche I praie god
sende you, wyth longe life to his pleasure.

<f type="r">F##sp##I##sp##N##sp##I##sp##S.
</page>

<page sig="a3r">
T##sp##H##sp##E T##sp##A##sp##B##sp##L##sp##E.

<f type="bk">A<f type="bl">Diectiues, longynge
some to the body, some
to the mynde.
Adiectiues of ordre, from the 
first to a thousand.
Adiectiues of numbre.
Aduerbes of numbre.
Affinitee.
Ages.
Aire, with that perteineth.
		B
&para; Baker, and brewer, wyth
other victailers.
Bake house, with his vessels
and instrumentes.
Barber, wyth his shoppe and 
instrumentes.
Bath, stew, or hot hous.
Bataile, with his app<expan type="e+_">en</expan>d<expan type="e+_">en</expan>tes.
Beastes that laboure.
Bed chambre, with the appa&shy;
 rell.
Bees.
Birdes.
Birdes of the water.
Birdes about the house.
Boultyng house.
Broderer.
Brew house, with <emend err="vesselsand">vessels and</emend>
instrumentes.
Buttry, with his vessels.
		C
&para; Carpenter, with his instru&shy;
mentes and such as worke
in tymbre.
Churche yarde and churche,
with ornamentes, and that 
belongeth.
Citee, with that perteineth to 
a citee.
Clothe maker of linen, wyth
his instrumentes.
Cloth maker of wool, wyth
his instrumentes.
Clothynge or apparaile
for men.
Clothyng for women.
Cobler or botcher.
Corne.
Corne field, with that belon&shy;
geth.
Corne market.
Colours of cloth.
Coriar, with his instrumen&shy;
tes.
Craftes men.
		D
&para; Deiry hous, or chese house,
with his vessels and that
perteineth.
Dier, with his colours.
Diuine seruice , with the ap&shy;
pertinenses.
Draper.
		E
&para; Earthe, wyth that belon&shy;
</page>

<page sig="a3v">
geth to it.
Ewry, wyth vessels, instru&shy;
mentes, and other, that lon
geth to the ewry.
		F
&para; Feire.
Field and lande abrode in the
countrey.
Fisshes of the sea.
Fissher with his instrum<expan type="e+_">en</expan>tes.
Fisshe market.
Fine wittes.
Flesshe market.
Flies and other.
Foure elementes.
Foure partes of the yere.
Foure partes of the worlde.
Foure footed beastes.
Fouler or birder, with his in&shy;
strumentes.
Fresshe water fishe.
Frutes.
Frute market,
Fuller.
		G
&para; Goldesmith.
		H
&para; Hall, with thynges belon&shy;
gyng to the hall.
Heardes men, haywardes,
sheaperdes, with such other
as kepe catell.
Hell, with thinges conteined
in it.
Herbes, gathered by diuers
men, speciallly by master Li&shy;
naker.
Herbe market.
Hogges.
Housebande man, with suche
other as laboure in house&shy;
bandry.
Housyng for the housebande 
man, with that belongeth.
Houses of office wyth vessels
and instrumentes.
Holy place with that pertei&shy;
neth.
Housyng as in a towne or ci&shy;
tee.
Hunter with his instrumen&shy;
tes.
		I
&para; Instrumentes of musike.
Instruments of warre and 
battaile.
Iter, a iourney, with that be&shy;
longeth.
Iustyng place.
		K
&para; Kechin, with his partes, 
vessels,&amp; instrumentes.
Kynrede.
		L
&para; Labourers.
Larder house.
</page>

<page sig="a4r">
Law, with the ministers
therof.
		M
&para; Maire of a towne or citee,
with the subiectes and com&shy;
minaltee.
Maires house.
Market place.
Mason, with his instrumen&shy;
tes and mattier, wherwith
he worketh.
Meales, as breakefast, diner,
and suppar.
Meate.
Medowe, wyth that belon&shy;
geth.
Mettals, and the place where
thei be digged.
Miller.
Ministers &amp; serua<expan type="u+_">un</expan>tes in the 
churche, with that perteineth.
Minstrels &amp; dancers.
		N
&para; Names of birdes.
Names of fisshes.
Names of corne, wyth that
perteineth.
Names of trees.
Names of wines.
Names of herbes.
Names of kinrede.
Names of affinitee, with the
appertinence.
		O
&para; Officers and waiters, as 
in a great houshold.
		P
&para; Pantrie, with breade and 
instrumentes.
Parke.
Partes of a horse.
Partes of a tree.
Partes of howsing with that
belongeth.
Partes of the body.
Phisition and surgion, with
the appertinence.
Places, where maistries and
plaies be shewed.
Place where market is kept.
Places for correction , and for
execution.
Place, where execution is 
done.
Plaiyng, with instrumentes
that belong to plaiyng.
Planettes.
Potage.
Poticarie.
Prison, fetters, pillorie, ga&shy;
lowes, and other.
		Q
&para; Quoyner, with his weigh&shy;
tes.		
		R
&para; Rennyng place.
Ruler in the prouince, wyth
</page>

<page sig="a4v">
his subiects, officers, and
that perteineth.
		S
&para; Sauce.
Schole with that belongeth 
therto.
Sea, with that belongeth to 
it.
Semster or shepster.
Serp<expan type="e+_">en</expan>tes, woormes, and cre&shy;
pyng beastes.
Seuen planetes.
Shell fisshe.
Sherman.
Shippe, with other water
vessels.
Shoemaker, with his shoppe
and instrumentes.
Sickenesse, greefe, and disea&shy;
ses.
Smith, with his forge, and
instrumentes.
Spices.
Stable, with that perteineth.
Stewes, with bandes, harlot&shy;
lets, and theeues.
Strife and wrong, as extor&shy;
cion, disceite, or thefte.
Surgion.
		T
&para; Tailour, with his shoppe 
and instrumentes,
Tillyng of the lande, with the
instrumentes of husbandry.
Towne, with that pertei&shy;
neth.
Times.
Trees, with that belongeth.
Twelue signes.
		V
&para; Vine yarde, with that be&shy;
longeth.
Vittayler, that selleth bread,
meate, and drinke, as in an
ale house or other.
Vncleanes of the body.
Vncleanesse of the soule, with
filthy qualitees.
Vplandishe village.
&para;Water bearer.
Warderope, with his instru&shy;
mentes.
Warre, and thynges belon&shy;
gyng therto.
Water.
Weauer, with his shoppe and
instrumentes.
White meate and egges.
Wyndes.
Wynes, with their names &amp;
colours.
Wine sellar, with his vessels,
and instrumentes.
Wood market.
Wrestlyng place.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brightness(n)"><f type="bl">Bryghtnes,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)wax bright(v)"><f type="r">splendor, doris,

nnam, <expression lang="en"><f type="bl">sometyme the bright&shy;

and of golde, or of syluer. &c.</expression>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fair and clear, as after rain(n)"><f type="bl">Faire and clere, as after rain,
</form><xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)wax clear(v)"><f type="r">sudum, di.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Clarescit,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">it waxeth cleere.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warm, by reason of the sun(a)"><f type="bl">Warm by reason of the S<expan type="u+_">un</expan>ne,
</form><xpln lang="la"><f type="r">apricus.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Apricor, caris,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">signifieth, in 
<expression lang="la"><f type="r">loco aprico este.</expression></subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="day, mids of the(n)"><f type="bl">The middes of the daie,</form> <xpln lang="la"><f type="r">meri&shy;
dies, medius dies.
<expression lang="en"><f type="bl">But</expression><f type="r"> meridies, <expression lang="en"><f type="bl">is sometime ta&shy;
ken for the Southe parte of 
the worlde.</expression></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shadow(n)"><f type="bl">The shadowe,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)shadow(v)"><f type="r">vmbra, br&ecedil;, &amp;
vmbella, l&ecedil;, <expression lang="en"><f type="bl">diminutiue.</expression>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Vmbraculum, locus in quo
vmbra est; </subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">the place where
shadowe is.</subxpln>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Vmbro, bras,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to shadowe.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

vel palunibus torquatus, quia

	<class type="mnemonic">Plausitat palumbus.</class></xpln></wordentry>

rynge about their neckes: but

doe vpon their egges.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

nim f&oelig;tura.

.i. locus vbi pisce, vel animalia
seruantur. Sed piscina dicitur, v&shy;
bi pisces tantum seruantur.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ditch(n)"><f type="bl">A diche,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)sink(n)" lexeme="(en)puddle(n)" lexeme="(en)ford(n)"><f type="r">fossa, s&aelig;, fossula, lacuna

riolum, vel lauacrina, locus est,

where menne maie go ouer, a
</page>

<page sig="c4r">
foord.</expression><f type="r"> Item breuia, or<expan type="u+_">um</expan>, loca va&shy;

<page sig="d3r">
<wordentry type="h"><xpln lang="la"><f type="r">Terra cum pertinenc.</xpln>
<form lang="en" lexeme="earth(n)">The yearth with 
that that belongeth to it.</form></wordentry>

<wordgroup2 type="t" object="Hell">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hell(n)"><f type="bl">&para; Hell,</form> <xpln lang="la"><f type="r">infernum, ni, tartarus, 
ri, in singulari, sed in plurali
tartara, rorum. i. locus in in&shy;
ferno profundissimus &amp; pessi&shy;
mus. Hinc tartareus, rea, reum.
Sed tartarum, ri, neut. ge. fex
vini est.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Auernus, ni, &amp; in plurali, auer&shy;
na, norum,</form> <xpln lang="la">est locus Plutoni di&shy;
catus. Hinc introitus ad infe&shy;
ros patere creditur.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="d4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Orcus</form> <xpln lang="la">etiam amnis esse apud in
feros memoratur. Sunt qui sty&shy;
gem existiment, per hunc iu&shy;
rare dij consueuere. Alio no&shy;
mine orcus dicitur tartarus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Gehenna, n&aelig;,</form> <xpln lang="la">est locus ignis &amp;
sulphuris, infernus, vel p&oelig;na
inferni.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Cocytus</form> <xpln lang="la">dicitur luctus, vel flu.
men inferni.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Acherontis, fe. gener,</form> <xpln lang="la">dicitur pa&shy;
lus infernalis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Charon,</form> <xpln lang="la">portitor apud infe&shy;
ros.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Cerberus,</form> <xpln lang="la">canis infernalis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en"><f type="r">Barathrum,</form> <xpln lang="la">voratrum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Confinium &amp; confinis</form> <xpln lang="la">dicitur,
quod simul finit, vnde consi&shy;
nes agri dicuntur, qui eodem lo&shy;
co confiniunt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup2 type="t" object="Hogs">
&para; <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hog(n)"><f type="bl">A hog,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)sow(n)" lexeme="(en)wroot(v)"><f type="r">sus, suis, porcus, ci.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Suculus, li, vel sucula, l&aelig;,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">a
sowe.</subxpln>
	<class type="mnemonic">Grunnit sus.</class>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Eruo, ruis, rui, rutum.</subform>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Eleuo,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to wroote as hogges
dooe.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soap(n)" lexeme="ointment(n)"><f type="bl">Sope or oyntement, to anoint

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Ador,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">is also an other kinde of

be vsed in sacrifice, which we
doe now call ducke bill, and 
hereof cometh, <expression lang="la"><f type="r">adorare. i. pro&shy;
piciare religiones.</expression></subxpln>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Far, ris,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">all maner of corne, or
meale, as well of wheate,

<expression lang="la"><f type="r">Sed far neu. gene de omnibus
frugibus durissimum, &amp; con&shy;
tra hiemes firmissimum. est
etiam genus tritici, </expression>with a

supra, vnde vmbrosus, sa, sum.
<expression lang="en"><f type="bl">full of shadowe.</expression>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Vmbro, bras,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to shadowe.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plant of a tree(n)"><f type="bl">A plante of a tree,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)set(v)"><f type="r">planta, t&ecedil;, vn&shy;
de arbores plantigere, qu&aelig; ex
sese plantas emittunt.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Planto, tas,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to sette Vines
or Trees.</subxpln>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Arborator,</subform> <subxpln lang="la">dicitur is qui putat,
vel curat arbores.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Operculare</subform> <subxpln lang="la">significat operculis
claudere.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vessel to keep wine(n)"><f type="bl">Vesselles wherein wynes be
kept,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)skin for wine(n)"><f type="r">dicuntur vasa vinaria:
vt dolium, cadus, idria, seria,
seriola, & cirnea.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Culeus, vel culullus,</subform> <subxpln lang="la">dicitur sac&shy;
cus, siue vter, ex corio factus
in quo vinum reponere so&shy;
lebant.</subxpln>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Vinarium,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">a substantiue, is
the skynne, wherein wyne
is caryed, as in a hogges
skynne or other.</subxpln>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Vter, tris,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">is also a vesselle
made of a beastes skyn: and 
somtyme it is vsed for a bottel</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parlor(n)"><f type="bl">a Parler or place to suppe in,
</form><xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)winter parlor(n)"><f type="r">dicitur c&oelig;naculum &amp; c&oelig;natio,
nis. Item triclinium sumitur
pro c&oelig;naculo. Vnde triclinaris,
&amp; triclinare, quod ad triclinium
pertinet: vt mappe triclinares,
&amp;c. <expression lang="en"><f type="bl">But </expression><f type="r">dieta &amp; c&oelig;natio, in
ima parte, c&oelig;naculum in supe&shy;
riore. Sunt infiortis etiam stiba<emend err="">&shy;</emend>
dia. i. c&oelig;nationes paru&ecedil;.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Tablinum,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">a wynter parlour,
or place to keepe wrytyn&shy;
ges in.</subxpln></xpln>

<expression lang="la"><f type="r">Est etiam Pr&ecedil;torium locus
vbi iudicium datur, vel taber&shy;
naculum Pr&aelig;toris. Sed tabli&shy;
num, locus hybern&aelig; stationis
atrio proximus, quod fere ex
tabulis constaret. &amp; locus, quo
monumenta rerum in magi&shy;
stratu gestarum ponebantur, vt
supra.</expression>
</note>

&para; <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marketplace(n)"><f type="bl">The place where

<xpln lang="la"><f type="r">Forum.</xpln></wordentry>

<note><expression lang="la"><f type="r">
&para; Sed forum quatuor modis in&shy;
telligitur. Primo, negotiatio&shy;
nis locus: Secundo, quo iudi&shy;
cia fieri solent: Tertio, quum
is , qui prouinci&aelig; pr&aelig;est, fo&shy;
rum agere dicitur, quum ciui&shy;
tates vocat, &amp; de controuer&shy;
sijs earum cognoseit, ac sen&shy;
tentiam fert: Quarto,quum
id forum veteres appellabant,
quod nunc vestibulum sepul&shy;
chri dici solet.</expression>
</note>

ipsos senatores significat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup2 type="t" object="Adjectives for the Body and Mind">
<wordgroup3 type="a" object="A"><alpha>A</alpha>
&para; <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abundant(a)" lexeme="plentiful(a)"><f type="bl">Abundant or plentifull,</form> <xpln lang="la"><f type="r">co&shy;
piosus, sa, sum. Vnde copia,
pi&aelig;.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="much, too(adv)" lexeme="overmuch(adv)"><f type="bl">To muche, or ouer muche,</form> <xpln lang="la"><f type="r">ni&shy;
mietas, tatis. Vnde nimius,
a, um.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agreeing(n)" lexeme="according(n)"><f type="bl">Agreeyng or accordyng,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)accord(v)" lexeme="(en)agree(v)"><f type="r">con&shy;
cors, dis. vnde concordia,
di&ecedil;.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Concordo, das,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to accorde
or agree.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Hinc discorda, di&aelig;.</subform></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Amabilis, le,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)worthy to be beloved(a)">qui dignus est a&shy;
mari, <expression lang="en"><f type="bl">he that is woorthy to
be beloued.</expression></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astoned for fear(a)"><f type="bl">Astonned for feare,</form> <xpln lang="la" lexeme="(en)astoned, be(v)"><f type="r">attonitus,
ta, tum, stupefactus, ta, tum.

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">Stupefio, fis,</subform> <subxpln lang="en"><f type="bl">to bee aston&shy;
ned.</subxpln></xpln></wordentry>

as that that is fete or ser&shy;

togedre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjectives of number(n)"><f type="bl">Adiectiues of
numbre.</form> 

<xpln lang="la"><f type="r">Adiectiua numeralia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup2 type="t" object="Adjectives of Number">
&para; <wordentry type="h"><form lang="la""><f type="r">Vnus, vna, vnum.</form><xpln lang="la">

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">In plu duo, du&ecedil;, duo.</subform>

<subform lang="la"><f type="r">In plu. Tres&amp; tria.</subform></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Quatuor, quin<expan type="q;">que</expan>, sex, septem,
octo, nouem, decem, vndecim,
duodecim, tredecim, quatuor&shy;
decim, <emend err="qnindecim">quindecim</emend>, sedecim, vel
sesdecim, Decem &amp; septem:
decem &amp; octo, vel duodeui&shy;
ginti. Decem &amp; nouem, vel
vndeiginti.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Viginti.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Triginta duo. &amp;c.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Quadraginta, quinquaginta,

ginta, Nonaginta.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Centum.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Centum vnum. &amp;c. vnde cen&shy;
teni: vt ccenteni pedes latitu&shy;
dinis.</form><xpln lang="en"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Mille.</form><xpln lang="la">
Sed hic notandum est, qu&ocirc;d
mille adiectiuum, nunqu&agrave;m
declinatur.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Duo millia,</form> <xpln lang="la">vel bis mille.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Tria millia,</form> <xpln lang="la">vel ter mille, &amp; sic
deinceps.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="la"><f type="r">Mille vnum. mille duo. &amp; sic
vs<expan type="q;">que</expan> ad duo milia.</form><xpln></xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup2>

children: Compiled by Ihon Whithals.
